Repealing the ACA can be just as harmful for perfectly healthy people. Need another reason to #ProtectOurCare? 

2 million: the number of young adults who have coverage through their parent's health care plans. That care would be put at risk.

A reason to #ProtectOurCare that is deeply personal to me? 

133 million: The number of Americans with preexisting conditions that stand to lose coverage if the ACA is repealed.
Another reason to #ProtectOurCare : $874 million in funding that those with opioid addiction issues need to help them deal with this growing and critical problem.

Let's look at some of the numbers from that @nytimes story and remember why we need to #ProtectOurCare. 

21 million: people who stand to lose health care coverage through marketplaces or Medicaid expansion.

Repealing the ACA isn't about policy, these decisions made in Washington by the administration personally impact every American. 

The @nytimes has a good reminder of how much of an impact this would make. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/26/health/obamacare-trump-health.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage¬†‚Ä¶

It's not enough to #ProtectOurCare for people with preexisting conditions, we need to strengthen it to lower #healthcare costs so that everyone who needs it can afford it. I joined my colleagues today to call for Congress to pass legislation that will do both. pic.twitter.com/orIgVnArqI
